newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX Jan electricity rockets toward contract high.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX Jan electricity rockets toward contract high.

text.p: NYMEX January electricity futures rocketed toward contract highs midday Monday on outlook of plummeting temperatures later this week and a meteoric rise in natural gas prices.
Natural gas prices at all major receipt points in the U.S. jumped in tandem with today's surge in January Henry Hub gas futures which posted all-time high of $4.420 per million British thermal units.
Electricity prices have been moving in lock step with gas prices for the past several weeks.
Forecast of well below-normal temperatures across the U.S. by mid-week was the primary trigger of today's run-up in all energy futures.
The electricity complex was also bolstered by strong cash prices in the western U.S..

The Bonneville Power Administration provided further impetus to today's bullish sentiments by offering next-day peak power at prices about $2.00 a megawatt hour (MWh) higher than Friday's spot levels.
In early western trading, next-day power for firm, peak delivery at the California-Oregon Border was quoted near $28.00 and the Palo Verde (PV) switchyard in Arizona near $26.00.
January 1997 COB futures were up $2.35/MWh to $27.85 after hitting as high as $28.75, just shy of its life-of-contract high of $28.85.
February COB jumped $2.00 to $21.50. Other active COB months were also higher midday.
January Palo Verde (PV) futures rose $2.90 to $27.58 after touching its contract high of $29.00.
February PV was up $2.60 at $22.90 after posting a new contract high at $23.50. March PV set a new contract high at $21.60.
Friday, COB's open interest ended at 3,956 contracts, up 86 and PV's at 1,834, down six.
As of 1200 EST, 188 COB and 69 PV contracts were sold.
